Title: Follow the money - Tracking companies' influence on politics (Sponsored by the Donald W. Reynolds National Center for Business Journalism)
Speaker: Ron Nixon (The New York Times ), Bill Allison (Sunlight Foundation )
Description: These days, the business of businesses is often politics, and by understanding the legislative and regulatory priorities of the companies you cover, you can provide your readers with critical information about them. Ron Nixon of The New York Times and Bill Allison of the Sunlight Foundation show you how to follow the political money and influence that’s so crucial to the bottom lines of businesses.

Title: Pre-day at IRE Conference
Place: See printed schedule for room information
Description: The optional sessions will cover computer-assisted reporting, Criminal Justice, and more. An additional registration fee applies.

Title: Uncovering danger with data
Speaker: Robert Benincasa (NPR ), Dylan Purcell (The Philadelphia Inquirer )
Description: Data can help reporters ferret out perilous situations from schools to the environment. Some data can uncover danger to life and limb while other data can create danger of the editorial kind. We’ll speak on ways to tell the difference and discuss case studies along the way.

Title: Overview of the year in CAR
Speaker: Mark Horvit (IRE and NICAR ), Megan Luther (IRE and NICAR )
Description: Be inspired and see what your colleagues have been up to with new data and creative analysis.

Title: Tableau for Beginners
Speaker: Ellie Fields (Tableau Public ), Ross Perez (Tableau Public ), Lori Williams (Tableau Public )
Description: Learn how to create beautiful, interactive data visualizations on short deadlines. No programming required. You’ll learn everything you need to build data visualizations and publish them to your website just like

Title: The ask: Requesting and negotiating for data
Speaker: Mike Donoghue (Burlington Free Press ), Ellen Gabler (Milwaukee Journal Sentinel )
Description: News, sports and feature journalists will want to attend this session to review old tricks and the latest techniques for access to data and records. We will discuss data requests from beginning to end: how to figure out which records and databases exist; how to deal with difficult public officials; how to get data in the format you want; how to appeal

Title: Covering justice in Europe and the U.S.
Speaker: Leo Sisti (L'Espresso ), Jeff Stein (Independent Journalist ), Fabrizio Calvi (Arte Television )
Description: In this panel, speakers will examine how journalists find sources and information in these different environments, using such well known cases as the CIA’s rendition of Al Qaeda suspect Abu Omar in Italy and the charges of rape against Dominique Strauss Kahn.

Title: Collaboration: Best practices, successes and pitfalls (Sponsored by John S. and James L. Knight Foundation, Investigative News Network and IRE)
Speaker: Evelyn Larrubia (Investigative News Network )
Description: As collaborations between newsrooms flourish, how do you handle serious  journalistic disagreements, such as how a story’s findings are described  in the nutgraph? We'll have a brief panel discussion on a case where  that’s exactly what happened, hear how the newsrooms handled it, and  hear your questions and opinions on the subject.

Title: Beef up your spreadsheet with NodeXL and PowerPivot
Speaker: Jaimi Dowdell (IRE and NICAR )
Description: Handle millions of calculations in a flash; join tables from different sources and do some cool network analyses with Excel. Yes, Excel. A demo of free but extremely powerful analytic tools.

Title: Welcome to the world of data: Now what do you do?
Speaker: David Herzog (IRE and NICAR ), Tisha Thompson (WRC-Washington D.C. ), Matt Kauffman (Hartford Courant )
Description: If you’re new to data journalism, the idea of working with spreadsheets, databases and web tools can be daunting. We’ll cover strategies you can use to succeed and show examples of high-impact stories you can tackle back home.

Title: CAR for managers
Speaker: Mike Sallah (The Miami Herald ), Christine Stapleton (The Palm Beach Post ), David Donald (Center for Public Integrity )
Description: Managing the CAR story means not only analyzing data and crunching numbers – the gut work that goes into so many solid investigative stories – but employing creativity in figuring out how to balance the numbers with the shoe-leather to produce the most powerful prose. Panelists look at a host of cases, including CAR work that exposed lazy regulators, crooked businesses and reckless polluters.

Title: Analyzing unstructured data for stories
Speaker: Sudheendra Hangal (Stanford University ), Eugene Wu (MIT )
Description: Often data doesn’t come in nice neat columns and rows. This session will give you a practical understanding of how to approach information that comes in inconvenient, unstructured forms: tweets, e-mails, reports, videos and other records. We will walk through several examples of reports that have analyzed unstructured data and talk about conceptual and concrete techniques to work with your data. We will provide an online tip sheet with pointers to further tools.

Title: Privacy: Where does access end?
Speaker: Julia Angwin (The Wall Street Journal ), David Smallman (Smallman Law PLLC ), Florence Snyder (attorney )
Description: In today’s technology-saturated world, it is increasingly difficult to protect communications between journalists and sources. This panel explores some of the technology and tactics that journalists can employ to protect their privacy as well as an examination of privacy laws that affect journalists.

Title: Collaboration: Story brainstorming sessions (Sponsored by John S. and James L. Knight Foundation, Investigative News Network and IRE)
Description: We will break into groups to brainstorm collaborative story  possibilities around four datasets, with the goal of returning to your  newsroom and launching into a project. The break-out groups will be:

Title: Embedding interactive data and live charts using free Office Web apps
Speaker: Harrison Gordon (Microsoft )
Description: Learn how to take your Excel workbooks and quickly turn them into part of your published story by using the free Excel Web App. If you have a data-driven story, chances are you already have an Excel workbook with the data. By adding a few extra minutes of work, you can have interactive and gorgeous datasets available to your readers online and as an integral part of your story.

Title: The new money trail: Tracking spending in an earmark-free world
Speaker: Sarah Cohen (Duke University ), David Fallis (The Washington Post ), Ron Nixon (The New York Times )
Description: In 2010 Congress banned earmarks, a legislative gimmick, which lets lawmakers attach pet projects to spending bills. But that hasn’t stopped lawmakers from trying to bring home the dollars. This panel will examine the many ways lawmakers are still able to get projects funded for highways, sewer systems, even projects to beneficial to campaign donors, in their districts or states despite the ban.

Title: Taming monstrous datasets
Speaker: Steve Doig (Arizona State University ), Jeff Donn (moderator) (The Associated Press ), Elizabeth Lucas (IRE and NICAR )
Description: This panel offers guidance on handling stories involving very big datasets, often with millions of records. It’s geared to both data specialists and dataminded reporters. Learn strategies for compressing data into manageable chunks, approaching wide data tables, and handling multiple look-up tables. Grease the collaboration between reporters and data gurus.

Title: Visualizing the story
Speaker: Maggie Mulvihill (New England Center for Investigative Reporting ), Phil Williams (WTVF-Nashville )
Description: The latest techniques for turning non-visual data into must-see TV and more.

Title: Investigating social networks
Speaker: David Donald (Center for Public Integrity ), Joonho Choi (JoongAng Daily )
Description: What is network analysis (aka social network analysis)? How can I use it in my reporting? We’ll cover the basic concepts involved in analyzing the connections between people and organizations. We’ll look at a project that analyzed the social connections of 1,000 high-ranking officials in South Korea.

Title: Protect Yourself: Legal and risk-management (Sponsored by John S. and James L. Knight Foundation, Investigative News Network and IRE)
Speaker: Jeff Hermes (Digital Media Law Project )
Description: The Digital Media Law Project will lead a session examining the         legal parameters of tax-exempt journalism, including: designing         organizations that qualify for federal tax relief and         tax-deductible donations; keeping a nonprofit organization         afloat while waiting for an IRS determination on tax-exempt         status; operating a journalism organization within the         boundaries of Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code;         and legal assistance and risk management techniques. The Digital         Media Law Project is based at Harvard University and has         provided valuable assistance to several INN members over the         past year.

Title: Tableau for Pros
Speaker: Ellie Fields (Tableau Public ), Ross Perez (Tableau Public ), Lori Williams (Tableau Public )
Description: Take your data visualization skills to the next level. In this class we’ll push Tableau’s capabilities further to create more complex visualizations. You’ll learn how to: clean and format dirty data, use multiple data sources in the same visualization, build more advanced visualizations and employ advanced interactive elements.

Title: Excel mini boot camp
Speaker: Jaimi Dowdell (IRE and NICAR )
Description: If you want to really dig deep, you need to know your way around data and electronic records.  This hands-on session introduces data analysis with spreadsheets.  In one afternoon you'll learn to sort, select, summarize and graphically display data.  With Excel's powerful formulas, filtering and pivot tables, you'll turn data into a tipsheet to help guide your reporting and mine data for stories.  Unleash the power of spreadsheets to help you ask smarter questions, work more effciently and produce more watchdog reporting.  Attendees must bring your own laptops loaded with Microsoft Excel 2007 or 2010.  Pre-registration is required, you must be registered for the pre-day and pay an additional $20.

Title: New ways to package for online, mobile and tablet
Speaker: Alison Young (USA TODAY ), Daniel Lathrop (The Dallas Morning News )
Description: Emerging mobile mediums -- tablets, smartphones and e-books -- provide new opportunities for storytelling (and revenue) for news organizations. At the same time, the Web at 20 years old continues to expand its capabilities

Title: Crime trends and statistics (Sponsored by Criminal Justice Journalists)
Speaker: James Allen Fox (Northeastern University ), Brian Haas (The Tennessean ), Ben Poston (Milwaukee Journal Sentinel ), Ted Gest (moderator) (Criminal Justice Journalists ), Edward Davis (Boston police commissioner )
Description: How to get the real story out of confusing crime data. Journalists, a policecommissioner and a criminologist discuss hot topics, including which crime trends are real and which aren’t and how some police departments may be downgrading crimes and skewing statistics.

Title: Catching the wind: Visualizing and repurposing public data
Speaker: Fernanda Viegas (Google ), Martin Wattenberg (Google )
Description: The leaders of Google’s “Big Picture” visualization research group will go through a case study, taking public data and making something new from it.

Title: There be dragons: Pitfalls of statistical analysis
Speaker: Jennifer LaFleur (ProPublica ), John Perry (The Atlanta Journal-Constitution )
Description: Statistical analysis can be a powerful investigative tool. But for the unwary, it can be dangerous territory. In this panel, Jennifer LaFleur of ProPublica and John Perry of The Atlanta Journal-Constitution will talk about how to avoid embarrassing mistakes, how to find the expert help you need and how to explain your analysis so both readers and experts can understand it.

Title: Best practices  speed presentations (Sponsored by John S. and James L. Knight Foundation, Investigative News Network and IRE)
Speaker: Kevin Davis (Investigative News Network )
Description: Lightning presentations from INN members

Title: Finding stories within maps
Speaker: Jacob Fenton (Sunlight Foundation ), Jeff Blossom (Center for Geographic Analysis )
Description: Your data tells a story – but you might miss it if you can’t put it on a map. We’ll talk about services available to visualize the geographic pieces of your story, creative ways to join freely available data sets to your information, and how to read – or misread – the results. Add some simple geographic operations, and you’re ready to go.

Title: Free tools
Speaker: Anthony DeBarros (USA TODAY ), Matt Stiles (NPR )
Description: On a budget? Who isn’t these days? But you don’t have to spend a penny to own a bunch of powerful and easy-to-use tools for gathering, analyzing and presenting data. We’ll tell you about some of the most popular free stuff available, from tools for wrangling, analyzing and mapping data to basics such as free spreadsheets, text editors and photo editing software.

Title: Campaign 2012: Following the money (Sponsored by Rockefeller Brothers Fund)
Speaker: Bill Lueders (Wisconsin Center for Investigative Journalism ), Al Shaw (ProPublica ), Jonathan Salant (Bloomberg )
Description: From the White House to statehouses, here’s how to get the information you need to find out who’s pouring money into the process, how it’s being spent, and what do with the data once you’ve gotten it.

Title: Illegal immigration and the police (Sponsored by Criminal Justice Journalists)
Speaker: Maria Sacchetti (The Boston Globe ), Eva Millona (Massachusetts Immigrant and Advocacy Coalition ), Ted Gest (moderator) (Criminal Justice Journalists ), Steve Kropper (Ma. Citizens for Immigration Reform ), John Sandweg (U.S. Dept. of Homeland Security )
Description: The federal government is stepping up identification and deportation of people in the U.S. illegally via a program called Secure Communities. A federal official, advocates on different sides of the issue, and a reporter discuss what

Title: IRE Board of Directors Meeting
Description: The IRE Board of Directors will meet at 4 p.m. Thursday in Boston as part of the annual conference.  The meeting is open to all IRE members.

Title: Gag orders and Whitey Bulger: What to do when your sources are silenced (Sponsored by Criminal Justice Journalists)
Speaker: Maria Cramer (The Boston Globe ), Dick Lehr (Boston University ), Jon Wells (WBZ-Boston ), Kathy Curran (WBZ-Boston )
Description: Reporting on sensitive criminal investigations can be a challenge when your best sources have been ordered not to talk. Hear from reporters who covered the long disappearance of mob figure Whitey Bulger on how they broke the story and how to get hard-to-get information on crime stories you are pursuing.

Title: CAR under pressure
Speaker: Stephen Stock (KNTV-San Francisco ), Keli Rabon (KMGH-Denver )
Description: This session will teach you the value of developing and using your computer-assisted reporting (CAR) skills while under the pressure of doing daily, general news or during a breaking news situation where all hands are on deck in the

Title: Demystifying Web scraping
Speaker: Ted Han (DocumentCloud ), Sean Sposito (American Banker )
Description: Some of the most useful datasets are on the Web, and while they don’t require FOIAs, you might need to do some work to get them into your spreadsheets. We’ll explain what it means to Web scrape and we’ll show you some tools to get you started with fetching your own data.

Title: Going international: Digging up information from other countries
Speaker: Gary Marx (Chicago Tribune ), Azmat Khan (Frontline ), Kathie Klarreich (Fund for Investigative Journalism in Haiti )
Description: As cost-cutting has forced more news organizations to close foreign bureaus and cut back staff, how are international reporters leveraging investigative tools to dig up information in and about foreign countries? Panelists will share insights into some of the unique challenges they have encountered while reporting in Haiti, Pakistan, Egypt and Mexico, and tips and best practices for journalists looking to leverage new technologies in international reporting.

Title: Party with your data! (Hosted by Tableau Public)
Description: Join us for free drinks and T-shirts at the Party with Your Data Happy Hour! First come, first serve - while supplies last!

Description: Please select if you would like to purchase an additional Blues Bash ticket.

Place: See printed schedule for room information

Title: What managers really want
Speaker: Camille Edwards (WRC-Washington D.C. ), Scott Matthews (CNBC ), Susanne Reber (Center for Investigative Reporting ), Stuart Watson (moderator) (WCNC-Charlotte )
Description: Deadlines are shrinking, platforms expanding and the pressure to compete is growing! So, what DO we want from you? With the need for stand-out investigative content at an all-time high, news managers are on the hunt for

Title: Excel 1
Speaker: Elizabeth Lucas (IRE and NICAR )
Description: Performing simple calculations and sorting.

Title: Navigating the federal FOIA maze
Speaker: David Donald (Center for Public Integrity ), Kirsten Mitchell (Office of Government Information Services ), Jennifer LaFleur (ProPublica ), Timothy Graham (Office of Informatics and Analytics )
Description: Obtaining records through the federal Freedom of Information Act can be like navigating a maze and, at times, contentious. It doesn’t have to be that way. Hear the director of an agency FOIA office, a veteran FOIA requester and a facilitator with the federal FOIA ombudsman’s office offer practical advice for making the FOIA process work and

Title: Uncovering violence and abuse in sports (Sponsored by the Dart Center for Journalism and Trauma and The Dart Society)
Speaker: Megan Chuchmach (ABC News ), Tom Farrey (ESPN ), Miles Moffeit (moderator) (The Dallas Morning News )
Description: Whether violence is part of the game or a hidden dimension off the field, reporters can use a variety of techniques to expose cultures that tolerate crimes by coaches or players or foster conditions that traumatize players. Veteran newspaper and TV reporters share some of their secrets.

Title: Video: What you need to know to get quality vIdeo for your project
Speaker: Monica Lam (Center for Investigative Reporting ), Bryan Staples (WTVF-Nashville ), Rick Yarborough (WRC-Washington D.C. )
Description: If you’ve suddenly found yourself behind the camera, this panel is for you. We’ll cover the basics, from framing to lighting, what equipment to use, techniques to get those great shots, and even how to take it to the next level with hidden cameras. Join us for “Shooting 101.”

Title: Investigating slavery in the supply chain
Speaker: Cam Simpson (Bloomberg News ), E. Benjamin Skinner (Schuster Institute for Investigative Journalism ), Michael Smith (Bloomberg Markets ), David Voreacos (Bloomberg News )
Description: Slavery is not a relic of the past; and to the shock and horror of many consumers, slaves may be making, harvesting, and processing our precious material goods. Tracing the every step of the supply chain is tough work. Four experienced reporters will share how they did it in the fishing, cotton, and iron, and U.S. military support services

Title: Incentives and subsidies: Investigating economic development claims (Sponsored by Bloomberg)
Speaker: Daniel Connolly (The Commercial Appeal ), Greg LeRoy (Good Jobs First ), David Cay Johnston (moderator) (Reuters ), Jim Heaney (Investigative Post )
Description: State and local governments give billions of dollars each year to private companies in the hopes of creating jobs, but these deals often deliver fewer jobs than expected at a large cost to the public treasury. In this session, you’ll learn how companies play cities and states against one another to get bigger subsidies, how to analyze the costs of subsidy deals and the studies used to justify them, and the resources available to investigate projects.

Title: Broadcast: The investigative newsroom
Speaker: Matt Goldberg (KNTV-San Francisco ), Mikel Schaefer (WVUE-New Orleans ), Kellie Cheadle (KING-Seattle )
Description: Investigative journalism is more important than ever. For newsroom leaders the challenge is to move from supporting units that are silos to applying an investigative edge to content across all platforms. What does it mean to be an investigative newsroom? We’ll share our experiences building that culture from the ground-up – from starting

Title: Gathering Internet intelligence
Speaker: Sean Campbell (Cascade Insights ), Scott Swigart (Cascade Insights )
Description: Organizations today leave a digital exhaust that can be seen across the Internet. While more true for larger, publicly traded organizations, smaller- or medium-sized businesses also leave a large smoke trail that can be followed to its source. Sean Campbell and Scott Swigart in this session will show you how to spot an organization’s digital exhaust at a distance, how to mine it for insights, and how to relate the information you find to other relevant

Title: IRE one day rate professional, academic, associate, retiree
Place: See printed schedule for room information

Title: LinkedIn
Speaker: Danielle Restivo (LinkedIn )
Description: The LinkedIn for Journalists tutorial takes journalists through the various features of LinkedIn and offers valuable tips on finding story ideas, sources, tracking down executives for interviews, promoting stories and doing quick and efficient research. The tutorial and a free one year upgrade to a premium membership on LinkedIn is available to all professional journalists (including journalism students and professors) and it’s an offer we extend across the board to all members of the media.

Title: Excel 2
Speaker: Matt Carroll (The Boston Globe )
Description: Calculating ratios and rates.

Title: Broadcast: How to get the impossible: People, paper passion
Speaker: Jeff Rossen (NBC News ), Tisha Thompson (WRC-Washington D.C. ), Lee Zurik (WVUE-New Orleans )
Description: Your boss wants the impossible. People who refuse to go on camera. Documents the government won’t hand over. Passion, emotion and honesty caught on-camera. Get tips on how to get what you really need when you think you’ve run out of options.

Title: The game plan: Deciding when to do what during an investigation
Speaker: Michael Berens (The Seattle Times ), Manny Garcia (El Nuevo Herald ), Scott Zamost (CNN )
Description: Connecting the dots is the building block to any investigative piece whether print or broadcast. But navigating obstacles requires a blueprint. Discover proven techniques to unearth unique stories. Drill deeper with interview strategies – who to call first, how much information to disclose? Bulletproof your work. We examine the anatomy of great stories and the steps to maximize impact.

Title: Investigating public pensions (Sponsored by the Donald W. Reynolds National Center for Business Journalism)
Speaker: Craig Harris (The Arizona Republic )

Title: Non-profit/For-profit collaborations: Navigating the terrain
Speaker: Robin Fields (ProPublica ), Terri Langford (Houston Chronicle ), Emily Ramshaw (The Texas Tribune ), Carrie Lozano (moderator) (Collective Works )
Description: When non-profit and for-profit news organizations partner to produce investigative projects, the results can be extraordinary. But getting from idea to execution can be tricky. From process to politics to publication, our panelists will provide first-hand experience on what works and what

Title: Sue me: Dealing with the threat of legal action
Speaker: Steve Chung (NBC News ), John Zucker (ABC News ), Brian Ross (moderator) (ABC News ), Andy Siegel (CBS )
Description: What do you do when facing the threat of a lawsuit, or after one’s been filed? And what are some things you should you do to minimize the chances of that suit in the first place. Legal experts from ABC, NBC and CBS offer guidance, with help from moderator Brian Ross, who knows what it’s like

Title: Ignored and abused: Investigating caregivers
Speaker: Russ Buettner (The New York Times ), Ryan Gabrielson (California Watch ), Carol Marbin Miller (The Miami Herald )
Description: A look at how to explore physical abuse, wrongful deaths and financial fraud at state agencies and private organizations that serve vulnerable people,

Title: Covering immigration
Speaker: Mc Nelly Torres (Florida Center for Investigative Reporting ), Jessica Vaughan (Center for Immigration Studies ), Ana Lourdes Cardenas (SomosFrontera.com/El Paso Times ), Kevin Rothstein (WFXT-Boston )
Description: Whether you work in a rural area, big city or a border town like El Paso, immigration is a hot-button issue that requires shoe-leather reporting and document digging from journalists. In this panel, we’ll show you where to look for big-picture problems with policies and procedures and give you tips on how to ethically and accurately cover the human side of this controversial topic.

Title: Paying for investigative journalism
Speaker: Robert Rosenthal (Center for Investigative Reporting ), Joe Bergantino (moderator) (New England Center for Investigative Reporting ), Anne Galloway (VTDigger.org ), Ellen Weiss (Center for Public Integrity )
Description: Serving as society’s watchdog can be an expensive proposition. Journalists at nonprofit investigative centers are on the cutting edge of the exploration of methods, techniques and tools to bring in revenue and support for their work. Learn what they’ve tried and hear about their successes, failures and what’s next.

Title: What are they looking for? Inside tips on getting a book or movie deal
Speaker: Esmond Harmsworth (Zachary Shuster Harmsworth Literary Agency ), Colleen Mohyde (Doe Coover ), Joanne Wyckoff (Carol Mann Agency ), Howard Yoon (Ross/Yoon ), Josh Meyer (moderator) (Medill National Security Journalism Initiative )
Description: Literary agents are always looking for the story that the reader simply can’t put down. This session will describe how to package your story into a proposal that will give editors and producers the incentive to turn your proposal into a book, and your book into a film.

Title: Getting data into Excel
Speaker: Wendell Cochran (Investigative Reporting Workshop )
Description: In the real world, your key dataset probably isn’t going to come in an easy-to-use package. This hands-on session will cover how to import data into Excel from a variety of formats.

Title: Managers: Building a watchdog culture in your newsroom
Speaker: Mike Connelly (Sarasota Herald-Tribune ), Shannon McCaffrey (The Atlanta Journal-Constitution ), Rick Pienciak (The Associated Press ), Kate Marymont (moderator) (Gannett )
Description: In a time of tight budgets and increased competition, establishing a watchdog presence in our newsrooms is more important – and challenging – than ever before. Hear from three editors on what it takes to build a watchdog culture, including tips on how to help reporters identify watchdog

Title: Talking your way to the truth: The art of the interview
Speaker: John Ferrugia (KMGH-Denver ), Raquel Rutledge (Milwaukee Journal Sentinel ), Ira Rosen (60 Minutes )
Description: What does it take to get the key information in an interview that will make your investigation successful? This panel will bring together veteran reporters to give you tips on how to prepare, how to listen for essential facts and statements in the interview, and how to ask the questions that will illicit the information you need. And there will be discussion of how timing of questions in a TV interview will bring the audience to a clear understanding of the main points of the story.

Title: Broadcast: Consumer investigations
Speaker: Cindy Galli (ABC News ), Hagit Limor (WCPO-Cincinnati ), Jennifer Savio (WHDH-Boston )
Description: You don’t have to be a consumer reporter to turn out compelling reports of high viewer value and interest on pocketbook issues. This panel will take you through best practices to organize, wade through and distill consumer investigations. We’ll talk inspection records and laws, where to find experts, and how to background and approach businesses. You’ll walk away with links to follow and story ideas to pursue.

Title: Google Fusion Tables
Speaker: Daniel Lathrop (The Dallas Morning News ), Adam Playford (The Palm Beach Post )
Description: Google Fusion Tables allows you to easily publish relatively large data sets. Learn how this free tool can help journalists create maps, graphs and timelines, mash-up different data sets and collaborate on data.

Title: Anatomy of an investigation: The Jack Abramoff scandal
Speaker: James Grimaldi (The Washington Post ), Jeff Leen (The Washington Post )
Description: For the first time, James Grimaldi and Jeff Leen reveal inside secrets of the Jack Abramoff lobbying scandal and show documents used to uncover the first scheme published in the The Washington Post’s investigation.

Title: Fighting for records and access (Sponsored by Sunlight Foundation)
Speaker: Caitlin Ginley (Center for Public Integrity ), Shawn McIntosh (moderator) (The Atlanta Journal-Constitution ), Jeff Pyle (Prince Lobel Tye LLP ), Elizabeth Ritvo (Brown Rudnick LLP )
Description: The panel explores public records practices across the U.S., with special attention to emerging trends in privatization, electronic documents, privacy claims of corporations and commonly requested records.

Title: Broadcast: Doing it for free
Speaker: Melinda Roeder (WBFF-Baltimore ), Stuart Watson (WCNC-Charlotte ), Aaron Wische (KNXV-Phoenix )
Description: You’re constantly asked to do more with less. What used to be a solid daily story is being pimped as an “investigation.” You feel frustrated and frankly pissed off. Do NOT despair. You are not alone. Our trio has tangible, real-world strategies, tactics and technologies to produce substantive

Title: Investigating disability issues
Speaker: Laura Frank (Rocky Mountain Investigative News Network ), Jennifer LaFleur (moderator) (ProPublica ), Jill Riepenhoff (Remapping Debate ), Kristen McCosh (City of Boston Person with Disabilities advisory board )
Description: Navigating disability regulations can be a challenge, but once you do, you’ll likely discover fodder for investigative stories in your community. Get tips on reporting about disability issues from reporters who have done it and from the head of Boston’s ADA commission.

Title: Pitch Your Book
Description: IRE has lined up leading New York and Boston-based literary agents who have agreed to see journalists for a limited number of 10-minute appointments.  Bring your resume and your best pitch.  Sign-up sheets for available time slots will be available near the registration desk.

Title: Showcase Panel: Investigating power
Speaker: Sarah Ganim (The Patriot-News ), Florence Graves (Schuster Institute for Investigative Journalism ), James Steele (Vanity Fair ), Charles Lewis (moderator) (Investigative Reporting Workshop ), Walt Bogdanich (The New York Times )
Description: In the spirit of the recently released multimedia presentation Investigating Power, which celebrates the great “moments of truth” in contemporary U.S. history and the journalists behind them, these award-winning journalists will discuss the ways in which they have exposed abuses of power in government, in the nonprofit sector and in corporations – and explore how things have changed in recent decades.

Title: Getting out of the bubble: Beyond traditional search engines
Speaker: Nora Paul (University of Minnesota ), Margot Williams (NPR )
Description: Google’s not the only search game in town. Learn about search sites that provide different pools of information and unique search features. Hear about resources to help with both targeted and serendipitous searching in the surface and the deep Web. Veteran researchers Margot Williams and Nora Paul will share tips about finding and evaluating new search tools.

Title: Media Lawyers Brown Bag (Sponsored by Smallman Law PLLC and IRE)
Speaker: David Smallman (Smallman Law PLLC ), Robert A. Bertsche (Prince Lobel Tye LLP )
Description: Here’s a chance for informal Q&A about legal issues. Bring your hypotheticals and your own lunch.

Title: Getting things done with DocumentCloud
Speaker: Marshall Allen (ProPublica ), Ted Han (DocumentCloud )
Description: Hundreds of newsrooms around the world use DocumentCloud to “analyze, annotate, and publish primary source documents” as DocumentCloud’s tag line goes. Join us to find out how others have built DocumentCloud into

Title: Broadcast: Going undercover
Speaker: Robert Powell (NBC News ), Rhonda Schwartz (ABC News ), Pia Malbran (CBS News )
Description: Three seasoned investigative producers from ABC, CBS, and NBC share their best tips for a successful undercover story: how to use hidden cameras in innovative ways to expand and strengthen a piece; the pros & cons of different types of equipment, and which situations work best for each; and the legal/ethical issues: when not to use hidden cams, and how to turn the “tourist camera” into a great alternative.

Title: Managers: Bulletproofing the story
Speaker: Tom Farragher (The Boston Globe ), Robert Salladay (Center for Investigative Reporting ), Marilyn Thompson (Reuters )
Description: Detailed tips and strong anecdotes on how to avoid mistakes in the editing process, including pushing reporters to challenge key assertions and acknowledging what you don’t know or what might mitigate the central premise of a story. We’ll talk about meticulous fact-checking, footnoting and sharing key findings and assertions with targets and sources, and common warning flags. We’ll discuss identifying errors of nuance and tone, and all the traps associated with failing to use precise language.

Title: Shadow banking (Sponsored by Bloomberg)
Speaker: Chris Arnold (NPR ), Jesse Eisinger (ProPublica ), Brad Keoun (Bloomberg ), Mary Fricker (moderator) (RepoWatch )
Description: Shadow banking was the epicenter of the financial crisis. It hasn’t been fixed. Great stories lie ahead. Yet few reporters understand it. While it probably provides half the credit in this country, we’ve seen how dangerous it can be. Experienced reporters will tell you what it is, where to find good stories, and how to tell them in plain English.

Title: Are you ready? Digging into breaking news
Speaker: Anthony Capaccio (Bloomberg News ), Serge Kovaleski (The New York Times )
Description: Tips and strategies for bringing an investigative edge to breaking-news stories, including how to develop a story in real time while using documents, databases, readers, and innovative tools to own the story in print and online.

Title: Building the digital newsroom
Speaker: Emily Ramshaw (The Texas Tribune ), Janine Gibson (The Guardian U.S. ), Michael Maness (John S. and James L. Knight Foundation )
Description: News organizations that succeed online understand that they must remake the newsroom to create something new. This involves everything from organization to incorporating the right digital tools. Our panelists talk about successes, failures and ways to keep up with the latest technological developments.

Title: International roundtable: Working across borders and networking
Speaker: David Kaplan (Global Investigative Journalism Network ), Carlos Eduardo Huertas (Revista Semana ), Jan Gunnar Furuly (Norwegian Foundation for Investigative Journalism )
Description: In a globalized world, local stories can quickly lead around the world – the food we eat, the medicine we take, the money, immigrants, and crimes in our communities. Join us for this informal networking and brainstorming session with journalists from a dozen countries. We’ll go around the room with introductions, exchange contact info, and talk

Title: Advanced Google search methods for investigative reporting
Speaker: Dan Russell (Google )
Description: Google is a remarkable tool with incredible capabilty, but it’s a system with a great deal of depth that’s not widely understood. This session will demonstrate many different methods and techniques for finding things you didn’t think could be found, as well as discussing some of the strategies

Title: Google Fusion Tables (hands-on)
Speaker: Daniel Lathrop (The Dallas Morning News )
Description: Google Fusion Tables allows you to easily publish relatively large data sets. In this class, you’ll learn how to create maps and more.

Title: Campaign 2012: Backgrounding candidates and truth-testing claims (Sponsored by Rockefeller Brothers Fund)
Speaker: Greg Borowski (Milwaukee Journal Sentinel ), Jack Gillum (The Associated Press ), Matthew Mosk (ABC News )
Description: Learn how to use records to dig into the background of political candidates, from financial contributions to criminal histories and questionable business interests. Tips on the potential and pitfalls of fact-checking efforts, including how to identify good information from neutral sources.

Title: Paying for political favor
Speaker: Joe Stephens (The Washington Post ), Duff Wilson (Reuters ), Angie Moreschi (James Hoyer Law Firm )
Description: Following the money shows who may be influencing political figures, from city hall to the White House. In an election year, it’s especially important to track what candidates are getting – and may give in return. Our panelists will discuss their work on how political contributions and lobbying have

Title: In-Depth Data Analysis at Your Fingertips: Esri Community and Business Analyst
Speaker: Brenda Wolfe (Esri ), Paul Overberg (USA TODAY )
Description: Paul Overberg of USA Today and Esri Analyst Brenda Wolfe will demonstrate how Esri’s Community and Business Analyst offerings can provide quick and easy access to demographic, spending, business and health data for any location. Editors and reporters will gain insight into how both Community and Business Analyst can make them more effective and efficient in gathering data for a story or verifying facts. Real news examples will be explored using the product.

Title: Managers: Making the investigative commitment and building the team
Speaker: Mark Katches (Center for Investigative Reporting ), Blake Morrison (Reuters ), Valari Staab (NBC Stations ), Lea Thompson (moderator) (Broadcast Journalist/Producer )
Description: It starts with a firm vision at the top and unwavering courage to pursue watchdog stories in the face of declining profits, heavy criticism, and competing news priorities. How do you keep the watchdog commitment firm and strong (and actually build something) when financial pressures are forcing newsroom cutbacks in most places. Newsroom leaders share their experiences, success stories and survival tips.

Title: Investigating sacred cows
Speaker: Dwayne Bray (ESPN ), Mike Feely (The Patriot-News ), Marty Baron (moderator) (The Boston Globe ), Harvey Cashore (CBC News )
Description: Investigative reporting is on especially sensitive ground when it takes on beloved local heroes and the most revered institutions. Courageous journalism can provoke fierce public reaction and even internal friction. News organizations’ commercial interests might be at stake. Panelists, who have had sports icons and even the Boy Scouts in their investigative sights, will discuss precautionary measures they took before the first word was printed or broadcast, how they faced a gathering storm of criticism, and how they managed delicate issues within their own organizations.

Title: Guilty until proven innocent
Speaker: Florence Graves (Schuster Institute for Investigative Journalism ), Alec Klein (Medill Innocence Project ), Erin Moriarty (CBS News ), Anne Driscoll (moderator) (Schuster Institute for Investigative Journalism )
Description: An exploration of the challenges and rewards of covering wrongful conviction cases and issues. This panel discussion will cover the important role journalists can and should play in investigating likely wrongful convictions, (academic experts say there are thousands of innocent people in U.S. prisons), the many obstacles reporters face and strategies for overcoming them, the challenges of cases with and without DNA evidence and advice about handling common ethical issues. The panel also will explore the major issues that contribute to wrongful convictions: unreliability of eyewitness identification, prosecutorial misconduct, police misconduct, snitch evidence, false confessions, and

Title: Google Refine
Speaker: Tom Meagher (The Star-Ledger )
Description: Learn to take filthy, horrible, no-good, stinking, messy data from an unaccommodating government agency and transform it into something useful with the help of Google Refine.

Title: On the beat: Businesses and corporations (Sponsored by Bloomberg)
Speaker: Jennifer Forsyth (The Wall Street Journal ), Diana Henriques (The New York Times ), John Russell (The Indianapolis Star )
Description: Corporations raise and spend trillions of dollars, build and tear down property, file for patents and copyrights, set up complex partnerships, sue and get sued, and otherwise file reams of documents every year. With all that activity, they leave plenty of marks for investigative journalists to follow. Take your stories beyond the usual sources and learn how to dig through bankruptcy documents, regulatory filings, lawsuits, and other helpful records.

Title: The year in investigative reporting
Speaker: Mark Horvit (IRE and NICAR ), Megan Luther (IRE and NICAR )
Description: Pick up some story ideas and be inspired with the highlights of some of the year’s best investigations.

Title: Analyzing the past, present and future with U.S. Census data
Speaker: Ron Campbell (The Orange County Register ), Paul Overberg (USA TODAY )
Description: From poverty to wealth, high school dropouts to graduate degrees, census data offers the best measure of your community. It also gives you basic tools of social justice reporting – ways to measure discrimination, inequality, segregation, overcrowding, diversity, walkability, assimilation and more. We’ll walk you through these measures, showing how you can use them to add depth to your stories.

Title: Investigating poverty
Speaker: Kimbriell Kelly (The Chicago Reporter ), Jarrett Murphy (City Limits ), Patricia Wen (The Boston Globe )
Description: More Americans live in poverty than ever before. But stories about poverty can be hard to sell, both in news meetings and on newsstands. Learn practical tools for understanding today’s poverty and antipoverty programs,

Title: Showcase panel: After News Corp.: How far is too far in investigative reporting
Speaker: Leonard Downie Jr. (moderator) (The Washington Post ), David Carr (The New York Times ), Brian Ross (ABC News ), Alan Rusbridger (The Guardian )
Description: As investigations of tabloid newspapers’ phone hacking, paying police for information and covering it all up continue to produce shocking revelations in Britain, a crusading British editor, a leading American news media critic,

Title: American FactFinder2
Speaker: Ron Campbell (The Orange County Register )
Description: American FactFinder: Satan’s spawn or psychotic nightmare? Take a friendly guided tour through the census website that journalists love to hate.

Title: Pieces of the past: Building your stories from archives and historical documents
Speaker: James Neff (The Seattle Times ), Alison Young (USA TODAY )
Description: Old documents – those wonderful, often musty paper records not usually found on the Internet – can be critical building blocks for both quick-hit and long-term investigations. This session covers key types of archival

Title: Turning your investigation into a book
Speaker: Mike Grabell (ProPublica ), Josh Meyer (Medill National Security Journalism Initiative ), Thomas Peele (Bay Area News Group )
Description: Book writing is one of the last bastions left of good investigative reporting, especially for those not still working for the large mainstream media outlets, and it’s a great way to make use of all that research you did for your

Title: Broadcast: Top investigations of 2012
Speaker: Tisha Thompson (WRC-Washington D.C. )
Description: NEW! Watch and listen as more than a dozen photographers, editors & producers behind this year’s winning entries describe how they did it and what they were really thinking when things got hard. They give a no holds barred perspective on graphics, surveillance techniques, “unscheduled interviews,” editing programs, “lack of video,” time crunches and what investigative teams really need to think about during huge breaking news

Title: On the beat: Environment
Speaker: Scott Fallon (The Record ), Kate Golden (Wisconsin Center for Investigative Journalism ), Tammy Leitner (KPHO-Phoenix )
Description: Veteran journalists will offer tips on investigating pollution and its health impacts in the U.S. and abroad. Topics will include: covering tough environmental issues even when you have no background in that area, deciphering chemical jargon, researching public records on toxic sites and piecing together narratives from documents and interviews.

Title: Mexodus: Student-Professional collaborations in two languages
Speaker: Ana Lourdes Cardenas (El Paso Times ), Lise Olsen (Houston Chronicle ), Zita Arocha (moderator) (University of Texas - El Paso )
Description: Learn to produce a student reported and professionally edited multimedia investigative project on immigration topics in two languages, and get it published by media outlets to boot.

Title: Access 1
Speaker: Paul Parker (The Providence Journal )
Description: The purifying experience of filtering your data. Learn to select and sort data items you choose.

Title: Identifying the next big investigation
Speaker: Wendell Cochran (Investigative Reporting Workshop ), Andrew Haeg (The Public Insight Network at American Public Media )
Description: Most IRE sessions are about stories that already have been done, and it is a great model. This interactive roundtable discussion is designed as work without the help of those attending. We need you to bring your ideas to this

Title: Juvenile justice: Is the system working?
Speaker: John Diedrich (Milwaukee Journal Sentinel ), Michael Laforgia (The Palm Beach Post ), Maggie Mulvihill (New England Center for Investigative Reporting )
Description: Finding stories in the juvenile justice system: What to look for when kids are arrested, locked up and sentenced. The panel explores ways of exposing dangerous lapses in information sharing when children are arrested, quantifying the harm that can befall kids in juvenile jails and assessing the fairness of harsh sentences for underage offenders.

Title: From community colleges to universities: Investigating higher ed (Sponsored by Lumina Foundation)
Speaker: Gale Holland (Los Angeles Times ), Suzanne McBride (Columbia College - Chicago ), Erica Perez (California Watch )
Description: Gale Holland will tell how the Los Angeles Times used public records, confidential sources and computer-assisted reporting to expose shoddy construction, reckless spending and pay-to-play contracting in a $5.7 billion community college construction program. Erica Perez will talk about

Title: Campaign 2012: How healthcare and the other key issues are shaping the race (Sponsored by Rockefeller Brothers Fund)
Speaker: Bill Allison (Sunlight Foundation ), Alicia Mundy (The Wall Street Journal ), Denise Roth Barber (followthemoney.org )
Description: A key component of understanding how campaigns are won or lost is understanding the role of special interests PACS and lobbies. This year healthcare and a few other key topics are playing a crucial role in who gets financial support and who gets opposition.

Title: Access 2
Speaker: Megan Luther (IRE and NICAR )
Description: Summarizing databases with counting and summing.

Title: The art of source development
Speaker: Jo Becker (The New York Times ), Adam Goldman (The Associated Press ), Susan Snyder (The Philadelphia Inquirer )
Description: From beat reporting to hard-core investigations, human sourcing is essential. Learn how to find and cultivate insiders in the know over the long-term, but also on the fly. How do you get people to talk? What do you do when someone walks out of an interview? This session will cover

Title: Investigating racial disparities
Speaker: Jennifer LaFleur (ProPublica ), Ben Poston (Milwaukee Journal Sentinel ), Sam Sommers (Tufts University )
Description: From traffic stops to jury composition, examining racial disparities can be tricky. Learn what you need to know to analyze race in your community. Panelists include a social psychologist who is an expert on race and social perceptions and journalists who have reported on racial disparities.

Title: Policing the police
Speaker: Gina Barton (Milwaukee Journal Sentinel ), Sally Kestin (Sun Sentinel ), Matthew Doig (Newsday )
Description: Police officers are supposed to uphold the law, but sometimes they break it – and get away with it. Learn how to uncover criminal conduct among law enforcement using data analysis, open records laws and shoe-leather reporting.

Title: Uncovering the private parts of public officials
Speaker: Doug Haddix (Kiplinger Program / Ohio State University ), Russ Ptacek (WUSA-Washington D.C. )
Description: Tools to identify usernames and e-mail addresses used by politicians and others; how to use that data to track the subject’s digital footprint. Explore dating sites, social networks and even the documents that reveal the “private

Title: Managers: Managing the multimedia project
Speaker: Sarah Moughty (Frontline ), Rose Ciotta (The Philadelphia Inquirer ), Anthony DeBarros (USA TODAY )
Description: Strategies and ideas for how to tell stories and deliver high-impact investigations on air and online, using multi-media tools including video interviews, data and interactive maps and graphics. Session will also share tips for how to orchestrate and deliver a multi- platform project and how to manage the collaborative relationships between partners.

Title: On the beat: Government
Speaker: Ziva Branstetter (Tulsa World ), Tom Frank (USA TODAY ), Andy Hall (Wisconsin Center for Investigative Journalism )
Description: Panelists will discuss how to incorporate coverage of a local or state pension system into a government beat, such as statehouse or city hall. Participants will receive background information about how to understand a pension system, including key terms that will make reporters conversant

Title: Broadcast: The confrontation
Speaker: Wayne Dolcefino (KTRK-Houston ), Tony Kovaleski (KNTV-San Francisco ), Anna Werner (CBS News )
Description: This panel of broadcast journalists will explore the justifications, techniques, and possible consequences of confrontational interviews, both scheduled and non-scheduled. Is it “confrotainment” or real accountability?

Title: Social media for journalists
Speaker: Doug Haddix (Kiplinger Program / Ohio State University )
Description: You know the basics of Tweeting and posting Facebook status updates. Now it’s time to take it to the next level as a social media sleuth – harnessing the power of Facebook, Twitter and LinkedIn, plus geolocation and analytic tools. Learn new ways to find sources, background people and companies, and break stories before the competition.

Title: Resources for journalists to leverage academic  research
Speaker: Leighton Klein (Shorenstein Center ), John Wihbey (Shorenstein Center )
Description: We will discuss our own database project, Journalist’s Resource, which curates academic studies and government reports, and we’ll examine trends in academic research that are useful for journalists to know about. We’ll also review other information tools that can help journalists dig into

Title: Access 3
Speaker: Elizabeth Lucas (IRE and NICAR )
Description: How to join tables, matching information from one file to another.

Title: Digging into housing scandals
Speaker: A.M. Sheehan (Advertiser Democrat ), Angela Caputo (The Chicago Reporter ), Mark Hallett (moderator) (McCormick Foundation )
Description: In communities large and small, there is plenty to investigate involving low-income housing. But it’s a topic that many news organizations ignore. Learn about the kinds of stories you can uncover, and the impact you can

Title: Truthiness and investigative reporting
Speaker: Tom Fiedler (Boston University ), Blake Morrison (Reuters ), Alex Jones (Shorenstein Center ), David Barstow (The New York Times )
Description: What happens to investigative reporting in an era in which careful reporting and factual accuracy are under relentless pressure from the competition and from the very culture? Is true enough (or truthy) trumping true? If the power of investigative reporting is to change minds, what if the facts

Title: Investigative reporting in China
Speaker: Ying Chan (Hong Kong University ), Liu Jianqiang (China Dialogue ), Chen Meng (The Time-Weekly (Guangzhou) ), David Kaplan (moderator) (Global Investigative Journalism Network )
Description: As stories around the world increasingly lead to China, that nation’s investigative press is growing and breaking news on corruption, crime, the environment, business, and more. Join some of China’s top investigative journalists as they talk about how they practice their craft in the world’s most populous country.

Title: Follow the money: The boom in toll roads
Speaker: Paul Overberg (USA TODAY ), Brad Guilmino (HNTB Corporation )
Description: For a century, building and operating U.S. roads has mostly been a government monopoly. Taxes have mostly paid the bill. No longer. Now roads are often built, run and even owned outright by investors. That means tolls. It also means that governments have to sift through a maze of ways to finance, build and operate a highway while still protecting the public interest. Find out how to follow the money in the booming world of toll roads.

Title: Promoting your investigation
Speaker: Jessica Plautz (Investigative News Network ), David Gehring (YouTube ), Eric Newton (moderator) (John S. and James L. Knight Foundation ), Rick Hirsch (The Miami Herald ), Nathan Tobey (Frontline )
Description: In a world of information abundance, how do you call attention to your investigation? Is community engagement only “promotion” or “marketing,” or can journalists effectively use new channels and new collaboratives to inspire debate about or action on stories? In this panel, we look at journalistic ways to involve the audience and build community around news organizations.

Title: IRE Awards Luncheon featuring keynote speaker Jill Abramson, The New York Times
Description: noon - 2 p.m.

Title: Investigating prison abuse (Sponsored by the Dart Center for Journalism and Trauma and The Dart Society)
Speaker: Susan Greene (Independent Journalist ), Jeff Kelly Lowenstein (Hoy ), Wendy Halloran (KPNX-Phoenix ), Cindy Chang (The Times-Picayune )
Description: The American prison system is under unprecedented pressures, with the legacies of overcrowding and tough-on-crime policies of past decades colliding with state budget crises. Panelists will discuss hidden and undercovered stories in the state and federal prison system, from solitary confinement to the impact of budget cuts to children of incarcerated parents.

Title: Broadcast: The paper chase
Speaker: Kathleen Johnston (CNN ), Ron Regan (WEWS-Cleveland ), Phil Williams (WTVF-Nashville )
Description: From uncovering key documents to tracking down elusive interviews, we combine successful broadcast investigations with useful tips from both traditional and non- traditional methods including the role social media can play in enhancing your reporting.

Title: Campaign 2012: What's so super about PACS? (Sponsored by Rockefeller Brothers Fund)
Speaker: John Dunbar (Center for Public Integrity ), Jacob Fenton (Sunlight Foundation ), Sheila Krumholz (Center for Responsive Politics ), Viveca Novak (Center for Responsive Politics )
Description: Representatives of three of the most experienced money-in-politics organizations in Washington – the Center for Responsive Politics, the Sunlight Foundation and the Center for Public Integrity – will explain the new campaign finance landscape in the wake of the landmark Citizens United

Title: Intro to Excel for elections
Speaker: Matt Stiles (NPR )
Description: Learn basic but powerful functions using spreadsheets to help you navigate election and campaign data. Come away with new data skills and story ideas for election coverage.

Title: Muse: A tool to mine and visualize large email archives
Speaker: Sudheendra Hangal (Stanford University )
Description: Journalists have often looked to emails and email archives to help research stories, but sifting through them can be tedious. Memories USing Email (MUSE) is a system that combines data analysis techniques such as automatic grouping, sentiment analysis and summarization with an

Title: Anatomy of an investigation: Behind the story with two IRE Medal winners
Speaker: Kevin Hirten (KTRK-Houston ), Corey Johnson (California Watch ), Kendall Taggart (Center for Investigative Reporting )
Description: Get a detailed look at how this year’s IRE Medal winners got their stories. We’ll go behind the scenes with California Watch’s multi-media “On Shaky Ground” project, which looked at the lack of earthquake preparedness in the state’s schools, and KTRK-Houston’s expose on corruption in a local law enforcement agency. Get tips and how-to advice on doing similar work in your community.

Title: Getting what you want
Speaker: Sarah Cohen (Duke University ), David Cuillier (The University of Arizona ), Jennifer LaFleur (ProPublica )
Description: Learn strategies for getting stubborn government officials to hand over public records and data you need to enlighten the public. The panelists will discuss how to find records, craft effective request letters, overcome illegal denials and exorbitant copy fees, and apply psychological strategies,

Title: America: What went wrong 2012
Speaker: Kat Aaron (Investigative Reporting Workshop ), Rose Ciotta (The Philadelphia Inquirer ), James Steele (Vanity Fair ), Charles Lewis (moderator) (Investigative Reporting Workshop )
Description: Twenty years ago, Philadelphia Inquirer reporters Donald Barlett and James Steele wrote the iconic series and book, “America: What Went Wrong?” Now, in online, multimedia collaboration with the Investigative Reporting Workshop, the Inquirer and many others, they have continued their investigation into how public acts and private greed in Washington and Wall Street have devastated millions of Americans.

Title: Managers: Picking projects that will have impact
Speaker: Stephen Engelberg (ProPublica ), John Hillkirk (USA TODAY ), Jeff Leen (The Washington Post )
Description: What kind of story is worth working on for a year? Three veteran editors talk about how to find compelling and revelatory investigative project ideas, how to refine them and make sure they demand readers’ attention and, ultimately, how to get them published in print or online with engaging visuals and other storytelling tools. And making lemonade out of lemons, or what to do when a story goes bust.

Title: Campaign 2012: Online tools for digging into campaign cash (Sponsored by Rockefeller Brothers Fund)
Speaker: Bill Allison (Sunlight Foundation ), Sheila Krumholz (Center for Responsive Politics ), Viveca Novak (Center for Responsive Politics ), Denise Roth Barber (followthemoney.org )
Description: Plenty of tools are readily available to help you obtain and make sense of campaign finance data. This session will help you understand how to put those tools to use.

Title: Excel for elections (cont'd)
Speaker: Matt Stiles (NPR )
Description: Continuation of 2:30-3:30 p.m. Intro to Excel for elections hands-on class.

Title: Broadcast: Going national
Speaker: Mark Greenblatt (ABC News ), Byron Pitts (CBS News ), Keith Summa (CBS News ), Stephen Stock (moderator) (KNTV-San Francisco )
Description: Hear from some of the best in the business in this session. Find out how to make your local story go national. What should you think about from the very beginning to get the networks to take notice? Three network journalists share how they got noticed on a national stage and how they make the work they do even now resonate with a wide audience.

Title: Investigations with class: Doing projects with students
Speaker: Marcel Dufresne (University of Connecticut ), Kathryn Quigley (Rowan University ), John Sullivan (Northwestern University ), Leonard Downie Jr. (moderator) ( )
Description: A steadily increasing amount of investigative reporting is being done by university journalism students with professional leadership in collaboration with news media print, broadcast and online partners. Four news professionals who became journalism professors lead a roundtable discussion about the various ways it can be done.

Title: Using public records to shine a light on the dark side of the healthcare crisis
Speaker: Daniel Lathrop (The Dallas Morning News )
Description: Deadly drugs, fraud and systemic safety problems at major hospitals are just some of the issues reporters investigated and uncovered in the  past year using public records. Learn about the public records  (including databases) that can be used to find wrongdoing and the  strategies to use them effectively to find and tell important stories.

Title: Tracking corruption internationally
Speaker: David Barstow (The New York Times ), Sheila Coronel (Columbia University ), Brant Houston (moderator) (University of Illinois ), Claudia Mndez Arriaza (El Periodico )
Description: This session will cover the methods, documents and human sources needed to uncover corruption, whether in business or government or both. Although international in focus, the session will also offer tips on how to approach these investigations from the local angle.

Title: Investigating the legal and justice systems
Speaker: Gretchen Gavett (Frontline ), David Jackson (Chicago Tribune ), Jonathan Saltzman (The Boston Globe )
Description: An understanding of federal, state and local laws can advance your investigations on almost any topic. This panel offers a primer on searching statute books and online resources, explores a remarkable project on drunk driving prosecutions, and delves into ways to use film and reporting to highlight cases and issues that, quite simply, do not go away.

Title: Investigating shadowy organizations
Speaker: Matt Apuzzo (The Associated Press ), Walter Robinson (Northeastern University ), Charles Robinson (Yahoo )
Description: Every reporter knows that one organization that just won’t open up. Maybe it’s an industry group, a nonprofit or a just an informal network of political power brokers who seem to call all the shots. This panel of reporters, who’ve unearthed secrets from the CIA, the Vatican and the NCAA, will give you the tricks you need to shine light on the shadowy organizations on your beat.

Title: Writing the investigative story
Speaker: Ken Armstrong (The Seattle Times ), Steve Fainaru (ESPN )
Description: If circumstances allow, write a story, not an exposé. Create suspense. Use dialogue. Shift perspective. Circle and loop. Experiment with Chekhov’s gun. Heed Elmore Leonard’s “10 Rules of Writing,” particularly No. 10: “Try to leave out the part that readers tend to skip.” Beware of formula and lose the bullets. (They’re more like tranquilizer darts, likely to put readers to sleep.)

Title: Collaboration: Leveraging the power of public broadcasters
Speaker: Brant Houston (University of Illinois ), Lorie Hearn (Investigative Newsource ), Andy Hall (Wisconsin Center for Investigative Journalism )
Description: With little support or fanfare, regional investigative journalism centers and public broadcasting stations have been teaming up to do multimedia in-depth stories throughout the country. This panel will cover how to carry out these collaborations successfully and with impact.

Title: Using Weave to provide interactive data visualizations to the public
Speaker: Georges Grinstein (University of Massachusetts Lowell )
Description: Version 1.0 of the open source Weave (Web-based Analysis and Visualization Environment) has been released. It is not just a visual analytic tool but an extremely powerful tool for the dissemination of interactive visualizations. In this presentation we’ll describe Weave and run though a number of example websites.

Title: Advanced functions in Excel
Speaker: Aaron Kessler (100 Reporters )
Description: Dirty, disorganized databases getting you down? Electronic records rarely come the way you want them – especially when dealing with government agencies. But Excel has some very powerful, easy-to-use tools to give you back control over how you want your spreadsheet to look. Never spend hours cutting and pasting again, or haggling with a PIO. We’ll show you some great tricks that will forever change the way you deal with data.

Title: Not-your-sob sisters: Three women who broke barriers
Speaker: Lucy Morgan (Tampa Bay Times ), Joan Vennochi (The Boston Globe ), Lea Thompson (formally NBC News ), Deborah Nelson (moderator) (University of Maryland )
Description: IRE launches an oral history project on women investigative reporters. The first woman to win a Pulitzer Prize in Investigative Reporting and the first two to win IRE awards will share the best of what they’ve learned about breaking barriers while breaking big stories.

Title: Spanish-language investigations
Speaker: Jeff Kelly Lowenstein (Hoy ), Omaya Sosa-Pascual (Centro de Periodismo Investigativo ), Mc Nelly Torres (Florida Center for Investigative Reporting ), Fernando Diaz (moderator) (Hoy ), Ricardo Sandoval ( )

Title: The legacy of Watergate 40 years later: A conversation with Leonard Downie Jr.
Speaker: Leonard Downie, Jr. (The Washington Post )
Description: One of the editors who worked on The Washington Post’s Watergate investigation talks and answers questions about what happened and its importance and impact on American journalism during the past four decades.

Title: Covering veterans issues
Speaker: Greg Campbell (Independent Journalist ), Henry Schuster (60 Minutes ), Michael de Yoanna (Independent Journalist )
Description: Three seasoned journalists will share their work and experiences regarding the hidden costs of war and issues facing a growing number of veterans as the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan wind down. From suicides to a frightening

Title: Let's get critical
Speaker: Al Tompkins (Poynter )
Description: Critical (not cynical) thinking is the hardest part of journalism and the mother’s milk of investigative work. We will take a high energy interactive romp through tons of real examples of lies, fabrications, photo alterations and video trickery that are out there waiting for you. You will

Title: Lifting the veil: Digging into national security investigations
Speaker: Trevor Aaronson (Florida Center for Investigative Reporting ), Josh Bernstein (The Daily ), Tara McKelvey (Newsweek/The Daily Beast )
Description: President Obama has expanded the number of covert CIA operations abroad and FBI terrorism investigation at home. But significant questions exist about the propriety of the CIA’s activity and the accuracy of the FBI’s intelligence on terrorism. For these reasons, it has never been more important for journalists to cover the U.S. intelligence and

Place: See printed schedule for room information

Title: Building your career: A roundtable discussion
Speaker: Sarah Cohen (Duke University ), Manny Garcia (El Nuevo Herald ), Stephen Stock (KNTV-San Francisco ), Len Downie Jr. (The Washington Post/Arizona State University )
Description: Looking for advice on how to take the next step in your career? Get practical tips from panelists who will talk about their own experiences and discuss what employers are looking for.

Title: Cool web tools
Speaker: Jaimi Dowdell (IRE and NICAR ), Mark Horvit (IRE and NICAR )
Description: The Web is full of useful tricks and applications to help you do your job faster and better. Learn how data and free online tools can boost your journalism and set you apart from the pack. We’ll show you some simple tools that will allow you to tell stories visually and more.

Title: Storyboarding
Speaker: Jaimi Dowdell (IRE and NICAR ), Mark Horvit (IRE and NICAR )
Description: Don’t leave the IRE conference without a battle plan for putting your new knowledge and skills to work back home. In this free-wheeling group session, we’ll discuss your story ideas, flesh them out, and develop strategies for doing them amid the daily demands of every newsroom. We’ll talk about navigating office politics and help you develop a personal action plan.

Title: Data and documents
Speaker: Megan Luther (IRE and NICAR )
Description: Advice on developing a documents state of mind, navigating public records, and how to create your data arsenal for high-impact local stories.
